utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: That crooked Adam Schiff, this guy is crooked. He had to make up a fake conversation that never happened. It was a total fraud. And then Nancy Pelosi said, oh, I think the president said that. These people are sick, I'm telling you. They're sick. She's either got one of two problems. She's either really stupid, OK? Or she's really lost it, or maybe there's a certain dishonesty in there someplace.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, to the president's point, he's saying he doesn't like the process, but I think according to the constitution, it's the sole discretion, article one, of the Congress to conduct an impeachment inquiry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: True. However, I do think that this White House's strategy of delay, and especially this week by saying this is an illegitimate inquiry, if you look back at the historical record, let's just take the Nixon one for example, you had a unified impeachment staff. So it wasn't Republicans and Democrats separately then coming together. They hire their own staff and it was a mix of Republicans and Democrats. Nixon's lawyer got to sit in. They got to subpoena. They got to interview. I think, as a process point for the White House, that is really good. The one thing about all this impeachment talk is that it is basically giving cover to the DNC on its debate process, the funding woes that they have. There's a lot of more stories going on that are problems with the Democrats than Nancy Pelosi and Adam Schiff's issues with the president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Katie, I was thinking, as Dana was speaking, that I think a lot of times in previous episodes of impeachment, the reason they have the vote to start the inquiry was to gain subpoena power. The rules have been subsequently changed so that they don't need it. But, it could be that you say, and I think that this came from Beto O'Rourke this week, just take away the president's talking point, have the vote, because the votes are there.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I mean, if they have the votes they should take the votes and, you know, put their money where their mouth is, and actually do a real impeachment process and issue real subpoenas and get witnesses under oath about what they feel like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, because they're already on record verbally, so taking a vote shouldn't be hard.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well -- and what Democrats don't want to do is open up an official impeachment inquiry because then it gives Republicans some power to do their own digging, and gives them more power than they have now as the minorities on these committees, and it forces Democrats to, actually, to have to work more with Republicans who have been asking questions about Adam Schiff's relationship with this whistleblower who heard the phone call from the White House, for example. So when it comes to the politics of this, look, Democrats are using impeachment as a political tool against the president in an election year. It gives cover to Democrats on the campaign trail who don't seem to get it together when it comes to their platform. And in the end, it comes down to credibility issue between Donald Trump and Adam Schiff. And given Adam Schiff's record with the Russian investigation, and now the questions about his handling of this complaint, people are going to look twice at whether they should believe what he's saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So, Greg, if I was to say to you, why are the Democrats impeaching President Trump, would you know the answer?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Pardon me? Why are they -- why are they impeaching him? Obviously, because they can't beat him. That would be my answer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you knew what I was going to say. That's why you asked that question. I realize what impeachment is. It's like when you're in a relationship that's not working out but you don't have the guts to break it up, so you try to get them to break up with you. That's what this is -- that's what this process is. The Democrats are just hoping that this will just drive Trump crazy enough to say, I've had it. I'm out of here. I'm too good for you, OK? I'm too good. Look at all the great stuff I got you, right? Lowest unemployment for minorities and women in history. I've got you prison reform. I'm making peace with North Korea. I'm trying to end wars. But you know what? You don't like my personality. You think I'm to mean at the rallies, even though I've been around for three years, OK? I'm out. Good luck with everything, with your Democrat president who's probably going to be an incompetent weirdo.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But that's not going to happen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's how I would do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: To Greg's point, I mean, you have him cutting a deal with China that's totally realign the world order in favor of America again after getting shafted by the Chinese for many, many years. It's good for the farmers. It's good for Silicon Valley. Listen, this is phase one, Juan. We just have to paper it. Paper it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're waving the flag here. Nobody see -- this is like NAFTA, he said, oh, yeah --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: NAFTA is collecting dust on Nancy's desk, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: For a reason.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's the reason? Because she doesn't want to give Trump a victory, and that's the reason. The point is, is they can like scurry around on impeachment, and subpoena, and do everything in the dark, and Trump is sitting there with the Chinese premier hammering out a deal with benefits the country and they're really setting themselves up for the do- nothing Democrats. They do nothing on infrastructure or asylum loopholes or anything that benefits the American people. And Trump is out there cutting deals trying to help the U.S. economy, trying to help families, and they're not doing anything. And everything they are doing is covert. You can't see it, it's behind closed doors, and it denies minority rights. And if you look --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: As you know -- you know that, in fact, this is the way the constitution is set up that the House acts like a grand jury --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK, then do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Then give Trump his constitutional --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's in his rights to look at the evidence --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The Senate is going to be there. The Senate will have the opportunity --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, good. We'll call in Joe.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, it's a political process, and I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or a ploy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- I don't see the wall. I don't see health care. You say, oh, Trump's doing --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a political strategy to solve a political problem.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, NBC struggling to contain the fallout of a rape allegation, very serious, made against former host Matt Lauer. All of this as Ronan Farrow, the author, continues to drop even more damaging details. You'll hear it right here on The Five.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: As the bombshell book that reportedly has NBC executives terrified. And now, Catch and Kill author Ronan Farrow is revealing more damaging details alleging that the network paid out multiple settlements involving Matt Lauer before the host was fired in 2017.

utterances.speaker: RONAN FARROW, AUTHOR
utterances.utterance: What we show in this book, with the paper trail, with documents, is that there were multiple secret settlements and nondisclosures being struck with women at NBC News.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: But those were after the fact. Weren't they the two nondisclosures?

utterances.speaker: FARROW
utterances.utterance: Nope, years before, over a period of six to seven years. A period in which NBC had previously denied --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: On Matt Lauer?

utterances.speaker: FARROW
utterances.utterance: -- any settlements. There were seven nondisclosure agreements, multiple ones of those were with Matt Lauer accusers. This is years before this incident with Brooke Nevils and the firing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Farrow also detailing how NBC spiked his story on Harvey Weinstein.

utterances.speaker: FARROW
utterances.utterance: They ordered a hard stop to reporting. They told me and a producer working on this that we should not take a single call. They told us to cancel interviews. The question for years has been why, because every journalist at that institution didn't understand why? And I think the book answers that question. This was a company with a lot of secrets.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, NBC has been pushing back as best as they can. What they haven't seen -- the book is not out yet until next week, and they've been taking this incoming and preparing for it for a long time. You they're -- got their work cut out for them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no doubt. To my mind, Dana, I don't understand why they haven't gone to outside legal counsel. Get somebody with, you know, hands that are not involved with NBC and said, here's somebody else. Take a look. Let's see what we find. I think that would give added credibility because what Ronan Farrow is saying is that there were in-house investigations done by people who were keeping their own secrets. These are some of the executives were having -- were forcing women into having affairs and the like. So, I just think that, you know, it's a nasty mess. I would like to have - - to see them take a step in an aggressive manner to clear the deck -- extend that to why this story on Harvey Weinstein was killed. Because, again, they say he didn't have it. He didn't have the sources. He didn't have people named or willing to go on the record. Seven weeks later is it that the New Yorker publishes the story. To me, that's -- it doesn't put it on Ronan Farrow. He's got to be right. But it does raise the question -- wait, in seven weeks he got all that done? That's a lot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Lots of questions being raised, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And Lauer, hopefully, is gonna answer some soon. He's been in talks with a few people to get his story out there, because, I mean, he must be dying to talk about this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I should mention Ronan Farrow did say in one of these interviews that he was asked, did you talk to Matt Lauer, and he said I can tell you that his thinking is represented in this book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Interesting. Well, and I'm sure there's some anti-Matt Lauer sources also in the book, too. It looks like a pretty comprehensive book, and it looks like now things people did and said years ago are now coming to light. This guy, up and armor, or I think his name is -- what is he, the president or vice president? Now has writings from when he was at Harvard. They were a little too -- I guess maybe misogynistic the people were pointing to, and there's a little bit of a brushfire growing among the staff at NBC, which they obviously have to contain because of those things can get out of control. But, you know, when you talk about all these old MDA's, or these old incidents that get reported to human resources, when these things happen in companies they handled them the best they can, and it's not always a thermonuclear war. Sometimes it's a smaller incident. And they try to do what's best for everybody involved. And maybe it's not handled perfectly, but I think they do the best job. And, you know, years later, looking back, if there is a pattern, that's just going to blow up in your face.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Greg, do you think Hollywood is going to make a movie about this book?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a great question because I think they've made a few movies about some scandals already. I haven't seen and I don't know anything about them. It is -- but the point is interesting. The news industry is kind of in a weird vice or conflict in the sense that they are filled with this sordid scandal, yet they have to report the sordid scandal because it gets eyeballs, right? We've been talking -- the book is not even out and I feel like I've read the book --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- because we've been doing free promotion for this book every single day. So clearly, people like to hear about it. And why do people like to hear about it? Couple of things -- books sell books, famous name, sex, and scandal. You put it all together and then you have a guy like Matt Lauer saying, well, wait, wait, wait, no due process, is like -- everybody is like, hey, sorry, we understand but this is a big story. I am curious about what he's going to do next. Like, what do you do? If you believe that you are innocent, right? And you've got the money, do you just move away because your career is absolutely ruined. He will never get another job in media, right? I don't think so. Being called a rapist, You just move and like leave to France where nobody cares about who you are, what you do, or do you take all your money and you fight until you're broke.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: He is denying the accusations--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Then he's got it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And detailing, very detailed about what actually happened and saying that it was consensual.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, he is fighting back in that sense.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But he's got to do more, right?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. But I mean the book is about two things, it's about NBC squashing sexual misconduct stories. It's about executives covering it up, paying--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then Harvey Weinstein gets involved.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right. And the other big side of the story that's not getting as much attention is the attack that he says on the First Amendment because he's been followed around, he's been intimidated, people have tried to stop the book from being published and that's his other take on this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He mentioned that Harvey Weinstein hired Mosad agents.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. So that's also a big part of his--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Follow him and--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's exposing all this, but also talking about the consequences that can be faced for journalists, not just him, but people who expose sort of things about powerful people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what struck me as big here that we're not talking about is the whole title of the book Catch and Kill, which is that somehow NBC was in a deal with National Enquirer to not do anything about Harvey Weinstein. So, they wouldn't do anything about Matt Lauer. That is corruption. I talk about protecting the rich and privileged.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, we'll find out more when the book comes out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We did talk about that the first time it happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, I said here today.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I talked about it two days ago.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We have talked about it all week but we--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm sick of talking about it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Move over Hillary, Democrats are now begging Chelsea Clinton to get into politics. That's coming up in the Fastest 7.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. It's time for the Fastest 7. First up, well Hillary toys with a Trump rematch. It could be Chelsea who ends up running in 2020. Democrats are reportedly begging her to run for Congress in New York after the unexpected retirement of a longtime congresswoman in that district, so Jesse would Chelsea be able to bring the Clinton dreams back?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a nightmare. Chelsea does not have any charisma. And I don't like to talk about people like that, but I will.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Run for Congress.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She just does not have it like her father has it. Her mother almost has it and she's not even close. Have you ever heard her speak? Have you ever seen her on camera? It's a total mess. She's got no energy. She got nothing. She's probably a sweet person, probably a very nice person. Probably great mom. Probably great wife. But in terms of a leader or someone that you can gravitate to and say, yes, onward, let's go, let's turn them out. No.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You should be a personal coach.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. Really inspiring.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Juan, do you think Chelsea Clinton should run for Congress.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don Junior on the other hand, lot of energy.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: There we go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. I mean I have two thoughts about this. One, because of what Jesse just said, it makes me think this is speculation that's being pushed by Republicans to raise money for whoever the Republican nominee might be to replace--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's wing conspiracy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It might be hard, but the second thought is that I don't even know that she lives in that district. But if she does, if she moved up there, I don't know. I don't know what kind of candidate she would be. The name ID, tremendous. I imagine that there would be some people who are just Clintonista's who would want to give her some money. But at this point this is pure speculation. I think it really is more to the joy of people on the Right, who especially can't stand her mom.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, there is some competition Dana on the Left for that seat. There are a number of people thrown their names in the hat. It used to be a Republican.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, let them try. Right. So, when they say Democrats are begging her to run, you don't need to beg, you're not going to lose that seat. You don't have to have Chelsea Clinton come in to win it for you. Why do you let somebody else give it a shot? There's lots of people out there. You don't always have to have the same people running over and over again as Barbara Bush once said.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's like prom king and queen. It doesn't have to be the same people over and over again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate that when name recognition is a form of entitlement. That's what this is. It's like what celebrities write children's books and they think that they're writers. You're not a writer if you write a children's book, OK. It's not - anybody can write a children's book even children do it. It's like this running for office like when - what's your name again Chelsea? Well, she's running for office, it's because she doesn't want a real job. She just wants a real job. She thinks her name is the resum,. It's not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, they're wealthy.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: She has said that she is not interested.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what she said.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You wrote Dr. Seuss. Who was that guy?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dr. Seuss.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He has a PhD, Dr. Seuss.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Speaking of--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did you see that movie about Star Wars, what was it called?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Working getting a job. Up next, 40 percent of workers say they are close to hitting their breaking point due to the pressures of their jobs. Here are some of the top things workers complain about doing including excessive workload, lack of recognition, pay rate, work colleagues and the work itself. Greg, which is your top breaking point?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. First of all, if your job doesn't risk you losing a finger and I are being publicly shamed by the media because you're a police officer, you shouldn't be complaining. But there are some tips. I have some solutions. Always start tomorrow's work before you go home, so you have a head start and you are looking forward to finishing it and then develop an interest in a hobby that allows for some improvement. So again, you have something to look forward to that is how you deal with work stress.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Life coach, Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: This is all. Dana--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of a book, I'm writing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not a children's book.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not a children's book.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Children's book.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Some companies now have lots of snacks out there for you and everything, like I just don't know what everybody is complaining about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Frozen yogurt.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What about candles.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it's noise.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What about candles?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Candles. Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Somebody with a candle in your office--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But noises--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's not like a workload.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I think somebody has a candle on our floor that stinks up the floor, Pete Hegseth.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right, Juan. What do you think about--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Pete Hegseth has candles.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He has a big candle that stinks.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, the Secret Service has a candle.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't mean that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: In the service box outside of the White House. They burn it all the time. It smells very nice. WILLIAMS: Yes, but that's the idea. Right, but it outdoors.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hegseth has a burn bag.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. I think a lot of people feel stressed out these days and I wonder about it because I think if you enjoy your work it's not that stressful, but if you don't enjoy it, if there's pressure and I think the pressures come from two things especially these days. The social media, electronic communication never stops.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, people are always like oh do this, can you fill out this. Can you come in. OK, the number two thing I think is people feel because of income inequality they are always like I've got to keep up with the Joneses. I've got to make more money, I've got to do this, so why don't I have a second source of income. And I just like I think it makes people crazy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, robots will take care of that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And then no one will have to work it out. It won't be stressed out at all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Yang will help us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Pursue our creativity.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Making candles.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: People say that Monday is their most stressful day of the week. I love Mondays. I think Monday is the best day of the week.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I don't have a stressful day. Sunday, maybe stressful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, Saturday and Sunday are stressful for me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You create stress for everybody.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right, will this stress some people out. Could you not survive doing laundry for five days? It happened to a town in North Carolina residents there, were asked to give up washing clothes because of issues with the water system. Jesse, how often do you do laundry?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Constantly. I do a lot of dry cleaning and laundry.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I mean--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Dry cleaning is not doing laundry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I fold and put away. I stuff and I load but that doesn't - forget it. Why are they not doing laundry, I don't get it--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Because they--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They had to clean up the pipes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean you have enough clothes to last five days a week. You just got to buy more clothes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's just means for you one pair of sweats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Allen Iverson never did laundry. He just bought new clothes wherever he went.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So that's the solution. Just buy new clothes. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that seems pretty crazy. Well, I mean but you know what, I understand it's a community issue, so go for it. But as long as people are washing themselves, I'm cool.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Dana, do you have any comments about--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Local communities do have a problem with infrastructure. We really do need an infrastructure week because the pipes need to be replaced.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, this week.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Not here.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's every week actually.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Every week, every week.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No laundry for five days are basically asking everybody to live like a 15-year-old.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: 15-year-old stink, they smell, they're sloppy. They're not good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but their moms do their laundry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true.
